If you’re keen on Labour, you loved it all. If you’re a don’t-know, Starmer and the party still have to persuade you why you should pick them and spell that out clearly. There is still a long way to go on detailed policy, although I wouldn’t hold your breath. I suspect the Tories will go long with the next election. They feel their polling numbers may go up if the economy recovers even slightly and that Labour’s will fall once the scrutiny of a general election is upon them. And no prime minister ever wants to leave Downing Street. I think we are looking at an election even as late as December 2024. Much can happen in that time including the two by-elections coming up soon.
But there is no doubt that the feeling of confidence and momentum is with Labour. You could feel it crackle in the air. “Things Can Only Get Better” blared out at every reception on the last night.

As tired, hungover senior advisers and politicians checked out of the conference hotel, there was a sense of accomplishment. They wanted to look like a government in waiting but they may have even exceeded expectations. A veteran political watcher remarked “this lot look more like the actual government than the cult who gathered in Manchester last week.”

title: The Tory conference is just like New Labour’s end days – funereal, chaotic and out of time
lead: There’s a distinct stench of quiet, inexorable political decay. I remember it well when I was a special adviser for Labour in 2009
author: Ayesha Hazarika

body.text: “Go on… Is it as mad as it looks from the outside?” That’s the same message I’ve had from my political friends not as lucky as me to make it to the Tory party conference. The answer is a disappointing no.

Last year, with the mayhem of Liz Truss and the mini-Budget, Tory conference was like a political zoo in an exhilarating kind of way. It was genuinely extraordinary to see normally quite sensible Tories marauding around all the late-night parties desperate to sound off about how the lunatics have taken over the asylum. Except this year, they are the ones in charge and it’s not going so well.

The atmosphere isn’t frantic or charged (apart from a brief drive-by from Truss) – it’s “funereal”, a word which was used several times to me by several political observers. There’s a stench of quiet, inexorable political decay.

It felt like there were far fewer people there than in previous years. A colleague was shocked to be able to get a seat in the normally bustling Midland hotel bar on the Sunday afternoon. But that’s what happens when you lose 1,000 local councillors – important foot-soldiers who would have often brought their families along. There just wasn’t any crackle in the air.

I recall a few years back when Theresa May was prime minister but Boris Johnson was very much on manoeuvres. Everywhere he went there was a media scrum and phones being whipped out for selfies. This year on two occasions we were told to stop and wait as someone important was coming and only afterwards did we even realise it was Rishi Sunak.

This is his first conference as Prime Minister and is probably the last one for the party in power. Last night, someone was frantically looking for a phone charger in the bar saying “I’m losing power…”
“Aren’t we all love”, quipped a jaded local party member.

You can tell when a party is coming to the end of its time in government. I remember it well when I was a special adviser for the Labour Party back in 2009. You feel out of time, out of ideas and out of control.

Just look at HS2. The spectacular mishandling of the Prime Minister’s announcement over its fate says it all. That the news is still dribbling out painfully while the party gathers in a former railway station in Manchester with a strapline about taking long-term decisions is beyond farcical. Watching the West Midlands Tory Mayor, Andy Street, host an impromptu press conference to launch a personal mission to save the Manchester leg with private money added to the chaos.

Labour, by the way, should work with Street on this. I wouldn’t be surprised if he ended up leaving the party or even defecting over this fiasco. Every Tory is mortified by HS2 now. The most charitable explanation I heard was that Sunak wants to get it off the books to clear the way for some tax cuts, but even that feels like a stretch.

And what about the big ideas for the country? A pick-and-mix of random ideas that don’t just fail to weave any coherent narrative, but actively contradict each other. Banning mobile phones in the classroom to protect kids (nanny state), but adults are free to run kids over outside schools because we need to end the war on cars. I’m hoping Sunak’s big policy announcement will be fitting all schoolchildren with airbags.

It was also notable to see how the role of the chancellor has been so reduced. Back in the day, George Osborne’s speech would be agenda-setting both in terms of policy and politics. Now we have Jeremy Hunt reduced to rehashing old austerity retreads like going after benefits and the Civil Service and making sure Nigel Farage has a bank account.

It was ironic that Hunt made Barbie and Ken gags, because he’s clearly a man with no political balls right now. Word is that Prime Minister Sunak is also very much still chancellor and rules the roost. I guess old habits die hard and he is technically First Lord of the Treasury.

This conference isn’t about Sunak. He looks like this is the last place on Earth he wants to be. He dashes in and out of events as quickly as possible leaving no trace. He pulled out of drinks with political editors. He basically hates it and the party faithful can tell. After all, they didn’t vote for him.
Related Article
What I saw at Tory conferences made me never want to go again

One of the under-reported aspects of the conference is that not all members are weird terrible caricatures. I was struck by how many activists old and young alike are deeply frustrated by the party’s lack of offer to a new generation and want to have sensible conversations about issues like housing. But that’s not what this conference is about.

It’s not even about losing the next election with dignity. It’s about what and who comes next. Everyone is jostling for position although some more crassly than others. One senior figure told me, “Suella has basically been pre-loading her leadership bid which has made her look desperate.”

Others may be doing it with a touch more subtlety, but be under no illusions. The next Tory leadership race is almost upon us. As a weary grandee observed: “This feels like the calm before the storm.”

title: Keir Starmer appears to have forgotten that the Labour Party is founded on principles
lead: What has made this conflict cut so deep into Labour is that it strikes at universal human rights and international law
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: When I worked for the Labour Party, I remember discussing the electoral significance of foreign policy with a colleague in my team. “Foreign policy doesn’t matter until all of a sudden it really does,” she rightly said.

Those words have been ringing in my ears for several days now. This division over the response to the Israel-Hamas war is about policy but it’s also about principles – and that’s why it runs so deep and so many Labour figures feel compelled to speak out. Foreign policy is politics at its most fundamental – it is about life and death struggles for peace and justice.

One thing it is not about (yet at least) is Keir Starmer. While Scottish Labour Leader Anas Sarwar, London Mayor Sadiq Khan, West Yorkshire Mayor Tracy Brabin and Greater Manchester Mayor Andy Burnham have all publicly used their profile and democratic mandates to put forward a different line, calling for a ceasefire, none have made it personal.

Even Labour’s rebellious frontbenchers, 13 of whom have now broken collective responsibility to call for a ceasefire, are not making it about Keir Starmer. There are no calls for Starmer to resign – not from the Labour left, affiliated trade unions or even the most disgruntled backbenchers.

However, the breadth of the division within the Labour Party is unparalleled. In Westminster, nearly half of all backbench MPs have called for a ceasefire. In Wales, while Labour’s First Minister Mark Drakeford has called for a humanitarian pause, “so that aid can urgently get to those who need it”, 11 Labour Members of the Senedd have called for a ceasefire. In Scotland over half of the MSPs, including Anas Sarwar, are backing a ceasefire. Among Labour’s affiliates, all are signed up to the TUC call for a ceasefire.

Over 20 Labour groups on local councils have issued statements backing a ceasefire (including Broxtowe, Leicester, Leeds, Glasgow and Luton). Over 30 Labour councillors have resigned from the party over the leadership’s stance – costing the party control of the council in Oxford and in Blackburn. Nothing like this happened on this scale over the Iraq War 20 years ago.

Twenty years ago, Britain’s entry into the Iraq War dominated every news bulletin. Tony Blair’s stance on the war, “shoulder to shoulder” with a neoconservative Republican president, divided the party immensely – and now very few people still defend it.

On a media round on Monday morning, Shadow Cabinet member Darren Jones rejected comparisons with Iraq. And on one level he’s right to: Labour is not in government and whereas Blair pulling back could have stopped the war, Keir Starmer is still only the Leader of the Opposition. However, it is worth remembering that it was from that position that then opposition leader Ed Miliband blocked David Cameron’s attempts to enter the Syrian conflict in 2013.

Jones went further and claimed that “Britain is not in any way involved in the conflict”. But that is really not true. The UK sells millions of pounds worth of arms to Israel every year. Many of the bombs and the planes that deliver them are British-made or made with British manufactured components.
Related Article
Air strikes always target civilians - in Gaza and everywhere else

When the UN condemned potential breaches of international humanitarian law (i.e. war crimes) by Saudi Arabia in Yemen, then shadow foreign secretary Hilary Benn called for the suspension of UK arms sales to the Saudis – much to the chagrin of some Labour backbenchers who had accepted Saudi largesse and hospitality. Benn once again sits in Starmer’s Shadow Cabinet, and a repeat of that principled stand could help cool tensions.

But it is unlikely, since Starmer and his spokespeople repeat the mantra “Israel has a right to defend itself”. Of course it does, but like all rights it is limited by the impact on others, and it does not have a right to perpetrate war crimes – which the siege of Gaza, indiscriminate bombardment, and alleged use of white phosphorous in civilian areas all are.

What has made this conflict cut so deep into the Labour Party is that it strikes at the fundamental commitment across the party that believes in universal human rights and international law, equally applied.

To believe this is about factionalism – or worse, religion – is to misread the situation entirely. As one Blackburn councillor, who recently resigned from the party, said: “The values of social justice, equality and human rights have been abandoned by the party. The humanitarian principles of the party do not exist anymore.”

When asked about growing dissent within the party, Darren Jones told ITV’s Good Morning Britain, “some people have a direct connection to the region”, and the issue was “emotive”. But this is not about ethnicity, religion or factionalism. Conflating high profile Muslims in the party with automatic calls for a ceasefire is borderline racist. Just as assuming someone sympathises with Netanyahu’s government in Israel because they are Jewish would be antisemitic.

Members feel patronised too. CLPs (constituency Labour Party) are banned by diktat from even discussing the most important issue of our times, while both MPs and councillors were given “very strongly advice” that they “should not under any circumstances attend” Palestine solidarity marches. Both a handful of CLPs and some elected officials have ignored such messages.

Damage is being done with every statement, every tweet, every failure to admit and apologise for mistakes (whether that’s over Starmer’s LBC interview or the visit to the Cardiff mosque). A leadership that looked strong, suddenly looks brittle.

It is in times of crisis that leadership is tested. This may not prove electorally damaging for Keir Starmer or fatal for his leadership. But, like Blair after Iraq, his relationships across the party, including with Labour’s dedicated members and supporters, have suffered lasting damage.

Unlike Blair, Starmer has a chance to put this right. He could re-unify the party by joining them and the international community – the United Nations secretary-general, the UN General Assembly, aid agencies like Oxfam and Save the Children, human rights groups like Amnesty and Human Rights Watch – in backing a ceasefire and a political process for peace and justice.

Keir Starmer said a year ago that the Labour Party should be “the political wing of the British people”. Well 76 per cent of the British public is calling for an immediate ceasefire. It’s time to be their political wing.
Andrew Fisher is the former executive director of policy at the Labour Party

title: The Israel-Hamas war is Keir Starmer’s greatest test – and he is flailing
lead: His missteps are already causing huge damage
author: Andrew Fisher

body.text: Labour may be the first opposition party to be in crisis over a foreign policy issue.

The storm began when Keir Starmer was interviewed by LBC on 11 October and appeared to say that Israel had the right to impose a siege on Gaza, cutting off water and electricity. Shadow Attorney General Emily Thornberry then repeated the point on Newsnight, refusing to criticise Israel’s tactics, saying only that “Israel has a right to defend itself”.
This caused uproar among party members – it was cold, lacked humanity for Palestinian lives and, above all, arguably encouraged the breaking of international humanitarian law.

It took nine days of growing criticism from across the party for Starmer to issue a “clarification”. When it came, it sparked a greater furore. It included no apology, insinuated he was misinterpreted, and that only Muslims had been offended by it.
He said: “I know that LBC clip has been widely shared and caused real concern and distress in some Muslim communities, so let me be clear about what I was saying and what I wasn’t saying.

“I was saying that Israel has the right to self-defence, and when I said that ‘right’, I meant it was that right to self-defence. I was not saying that Israel had the right to cut off water, food, fuel or medicines.”

The hollowness of Starmer’s clarification was further exposed at the weekend when Lisa Nandy, shadow Secretary of State for International Development, was asked multiple times on the BBC whether Israel breached international law when it cut off power and water to Gaza. She refused to answer, so if Labour’s position has changed, it is only from saying “Israel does have that right”, to refusing to say whether Israel has that right.

Labour’s response so far has made it seem that it doesn’t consider Palestinian civilian lives as important as Israel’s “right”. It is clear that this has deeply hurt Labour’s Muslim community, many of who who already feel the party under Starmer has become less critical of Israel’s decades-long treatment of Gazans – which have been deemed illegal by the UN – as well as not taking seriously Islamophobia within the party.

The Labour Muslim Network has put out a call for Muslim Labour councillors to sign a joint letter calling for the Labour leadership to back an immediate ceasefire in Gaza. It has now been signed by more than half of Labour’s 500 Muslim councillors – and support continues to grow. The Labour Muslim Network said it was “an unprecedented letter of unity from Muslim Labour representatives shows the strength of feeling throughout the nation and in our communities.”

Things were made worse when, earlier this week, Keir Starmer put out a tweet and photographs from a visit to a mosque in Cardiff, with accompanying text including that he was “grateful to hear from the Muslim community” and that “I repeated our call for all hostages to be released”. The mosque has put out a statement stating that they felt “gravely misrepresented” and that congregants challenged Starmer over his statements on Israeli war crimes and demanded he backed calls for a ceasefire.
One senior Muslim Labour source told me “every intervention is making it worse” and that Labour risks “the complete dismantlement of one if its most loyal voter bases”.

More than 20 Labour councillors throughout the country have already resigned from the party. Many, but by no means all, are Muslims. In Oxford eight Labour councillors have resigned, costing the party its majority control. Meanwhile, groups of councillors in Walsall, Leicester and Kirklees have written to the Labour leader urging him to change course.

Scottish Labour has distanced itself too – with frontbench spokesperson Pauline McNeill MSP attending a solidarity demonstration calling for a ceasefire in Glasgow at the weekend. Despite the diktat from Labour HQ in London banning councillors and MPs from attendance, McNeill told the thousands assembled she was there on behalf of Scottish Labour and “absolutely nothing could stop me being here today with you”.
Labour councillor sources tell me that we are fast reaching a tipping point and if Labour’s position does not change then more resignations will come.

So far Labour has avoided a Robin Cook moment. The principled late former Foreign Secretary resigned from Tony Blair’s cabinet on the eve of the Iraq war. But it has been reported that Cabinet member,  including shadow Justice Secretary Shabana Mahmood, and shadow Transport Secretary Louise Haigh have raised their concerns bluntly in shadow cabinet. Shadow cabinet sources tell me that Thangam Debbonaire, Lisa Nandy, and Lucy Powell (among others) have also criticised the position taken by Keir Starmer.
Related Article
The Labour Party is splintering because of Starmer's cold response to Palestinian suffering

Other frontbenchers are rumoured to be considering resigning. At Prime Minister’s Questions, shadow Women and Equalities Minister Yasmin Qureshi became the first Labour frontbencher to break ranks and demand a ceasefire. After PMQs, Starmer and deputy leader Angela Rayner were due to meet the party’s Muslim MPs and peers who demanded the meeting.

But this is not just about Muslim Labour members, or even just Labour voters. Opinion polls show 76 per cent of the British public back an immediate ceasefire. Every other opposition party in Parliament – the Greens, Plaid Cyrmu, the SNP, and on Wednesday the Liberal Democrats too – have called for a ceasefire. Starmer has only gone as far as supporting humanitarian pauses.

The Forde Report, commissioned by Keir Starmer in 2020 and published in 2022, heard evidence that “Islamophobia is not treated with the same seriousness within the Labour Party as other forms of racism”. For some members, the Labour frontbench downplaying war crimes against Gaza’s mostly Muslim population is another indication of that.

This is the gravest test yet for Starmer’s leadership – and his missteps are already causing huge damage. This may not be an electoral test (the Tories are in freefall as last week’s by-elections prove), but Starmer’s unprincipled and clumsy positioning is losing councillors, members and respect, even among his normally loyal MPs.Andrew Fisher is the former executive director of policy at the Labour Party

title: Keir Starmer battling to contain growing Labour unrest over Israel-Gaza stance
lead: Labour council leaders are growing concerned over the party leadership’s comments over Gaza
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: Sir Keir Starmer is battling to contain growing unrest among Labour council leaders over the party’s stance on the Israel-Hamas conflict.

The Labour leadership held a meeting with dozens of council leaders from across the country on Monday evening amid an increasing backlash to Sir Keir’s comments in support of Israel’s bombardment of the Gaza strip.

Shadow Foreign Secretary David Lammy and the Labour leader’s chief of staff Sue Gray met council leaders with large Muslim communities, who warned that support for the party was “in freefall” as a result of Labour’s stance on the conflict.
Several Labour councillors resigned from the party this week in protest against Sir Keir’s backing of Israel’s decision to cut all water, food and electricity into Gaza as part of a “siege”.

Among them was Councillor Amna Abdullatif, the first Muslim woman to be elected to Manchester City Council, who released a resignation statement, saying she was “appalled by the lack of humanity being shown to Palestinians by the party I have been a member of for the last 10 years”.

Ms Abdullatif added on Twitter/X: “I am devastated to now have no choice other than to resign the Labour whip and from the Labour Party due to Keir Starmer and a number of his frontbench making horrifying comments about Israel having the right to withhold fuel, water, food and electricity from the 2.2m Palestinians trapped in Gaza, effectively endorsing a war crime.”
Statement of resignation from the Labour Party, Cllr Amna Abdullatif, Manchester City Council. pic.twitter.com/8Wap2EFUjI

Two further Labour councillors on Oxford City Council also quit the party, councillors Shaista Aziz and Amar Latif, who released a joint statement saying they were “deeply disappointed and alarmed” by comments made by Sir Keir “seeming to condone the use of collective punishment against the people of Gaza”.
Ms Aziz told the Oxford Mail: “Like all decent-minded people, we are devastated by the atrocities carried out by Hamas in Israel. However, we are appalled by the words of Keir Starmer.”

i understands that some council leaders demanded the Labour leader explicitly apologise for his comments on LBC last week, when he insisted that “Israel has the right” to withhold power and water from Gaza.
Although he added: “Obviously, everything should be done within international law.”

According to those present at the emergency meeting, which was called with just two hours’ notice due to the outcry within the Association of Labour Councillors, Ms Gray and Mr Lammy said the situation in Israel and Gaza could go on for weeks.

One council leader told Informfully there was an “extraordinary disconnect” between the Labour leadership and the party’s council leaders, with suggestions that a second meeting could be held on Tuesday evening in a bid to ease concerns.
Labour has been approached for comment.

title: Why is it easier to talk about death than dementia?
lead: Government interventions on a healthy society are about as half-hearted as our own efforts to confront what might happen in our own old age
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Who really wants to face up to dementia? It’s one of those illnesses that, despite its prevalence, most of us would rather not think about, much less entertain the prospect of developing it. I’d wager that more of us are comfortable with thinking about our own deaths than we are contemplating what might come before. It’s hardly a slim risk, though, is it. There are currently around 900,000 people in the UK with dementia, and by the age of 90, around a third of people have the condition.

The odds aren’t getting better, either. This week, a study by University College London warned that by 2040, the number of people with dementia will nearly double to 1.7 million. This was a new study that put the forecast of future cases 42 per cent higher than previously predicted, and its lead author Dr Yuntao Chen warned that as well as the devastation that dementia causes in families, “it will also put a considerably larger burden on health and social care than current forecasts predict”.

It’s not as though policymakers have been doing much about the current forecasts, though. The health and social care systems are manifestly not coping with the current number of sufferers. Diagnosis of the specific type of dementia can take up to two years, meaning people with worrying symptoms are left in the dark about their prognosis. Then, sufferers are often just handed a leaflet with some information on, and left to get on with it – or not – themselves.
If they can’t cope by themselves, or with the help of family, then people with dementia end up in a system that can be more bewildering and frustration than their actual condition: social care.

We do not have an accurate picture of how well councils are meeting the demand in their areas, because they are not required to collect the data. The Association of Directors of Adult Social Services says 430,000 people were waiting for care, with three quarters of its members saying they “aren’t confident” about being able to meet the minimum level of support – even though it is required by law.

There have been some small boosts to social care funding, including the £600m announced in the summer for workforce funding over the next two years, and the rest going to local authorities under the most pressure.

But this government has not reformed social care funding and provision, and will not do it before the next election. Neither will Labour: Keir Starmer admitted to me in an interview at the start of this year that full reform would be a second-term issue, and the party may well leave it out of its manifesto.

Both Conservatives and Labour prefer to talk about the importance of preventive healthcare, something I’ve covered a fair bit in this column before. It’s a great idea, but it’s also not clear from either party what it would actually entail.

The rise in dementia cases could, according to the UCL team, be driven in part by the “epidemic” of obesity and type 2 diabetes, which are risk factors for the illness. But once again, politicians don’t really want to engage with what this means, because whenever they make a half-hearted attempt to talk about a healthy society, they tie themselves in knots.
Related Article
More of us will get dementia - ignoring it now will only hurt in the future

Often, they really just mean moving things around in the NHS, which is all very well and good, but prevention that really works would have to go far beyond the health service and into wider society. Too often debates about obesity end up with politicians fretting that they are suggesting people don’t have enough willpower to maintain a healthy weight – without wondering whether it might be that society is making it increasingly difficult to be healthy.

It might be the way the planning system doesn’t encourage active travel within or between places, and still suggests that the world is ruled by cars that need lots of public land to recline on, rather than people with bodies that need to move. It might be the way we think a “sugar tax” will make a blind bit of difference to the fact that the modern diet has become so palatable and highly calorific that it is quite hard work to consume food that doesn’t take you over your energy needs. It might be that for many adults, calories have become such an emotionally-charged expression of energy needs that they don’t want to see them on menus, even while they’re perfectly keen to see how much the food costs to buy.

Government interventions are about as half-hearted as our own efforts to confront what might happen in our own old age. Westminster seems content to bury its head even deeper in the sand. But as those on the waiting lists for dementia care know, pretending a problem isn’t really there doesn’t make it go away.

title: There will be more NHS strikes under Labour – this is how Wes Streeting can solve them
lead: There are more battles with the British Medical Association on the horizon
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Can the NHS really be reformed? Usually, when someone poses this question, the first answer is: no, because voters are so religiously in love with it that they won’t allow it to be changed. This is obviously nonsense, because governments have spent the past 30 years moving the health service around like a child’s train set, and Brits spend almost as much time talking about the need for the NHS to improve as they do about the weather.
What anyone who talks about opponents of reform really means is not normal people, but the British Medical Association.

The BMA is busy fighting the Conservative government on pay at the moment, with both consultants and juniors continuing with strike action. Rishi Sunak has been exasperated by some of the negotiating positions these doctors have taken at the last minute, though, and openly complained about what he saw as unreasonable demands in his conference speech last week. Nonetheless, a deal is much closer for the consultants, who have always been the least hungry for walkouts.

Sunak thinks the strikes are being held largely to embarrass the Conservative government, with the BMA backing that line up by saying the attitude of the SNP government has meant Scotland has avoided walkouts. Meanwhile, this week shadow Health Secretary Wes Streeting argued at the Labour conference he could get the parties back round the table.

But the BMA’s junior members are now so wound up and emotionally exhausted by years of working in Covid and backlog chaos that it will be very difficult even after the strikes are resolved for any health secretary to do much with the health service without the trade union kicking off again. And Streeting isn’t proposing to quieten things down in the NHS. The two policy areas that dominated conference were planning reform and the health service. Keir Starmer promised in his own speech that Labour would be the party that “finally transforms the NHS”.

Streeting wants to rebalance the health service from a focus on acute, hospital-based care to primary and community services. It makes a lot of sense, but there is no indication from Shadow Chancellor Rachel Reeves, who gave a rather scary speech about fiscal discipline to the meeting in Liverpool, that she would be inclined to maintain the level of funding for acute while also pumping more money into the earlier end of the patient journey. So, the money must move, and that tends to mean closing hospitals, possibly even before they are rendered superfluous by a whizzy preventive system. Just wait for the BMA reaction to that.
Related Article
Starmer's defiant speech after glitter protest revealed the kind of leader he is under pressure

There is a way through. The BMA isn’t the sum total of the medical world. If that were the case, the NHS simply wouldn’t exist, given that union fought tooth and nail against its creation back in the mid-40s. What got the health service over the line then, and might yet be its saviour this time around, is a group of far more august institutions.

The Medical Royal Colleges are a funny mix of educators and industry bodies. Doctors currently have to pass their exams in order to progress to consultant level and within specialties. They also bang the drum for their disciplines: more emergency medicine doctors, fewer targets in radiology, and so on. In 1948, they were critical to the very existence of the NHS. Labour’s health minister Nye Bevan made it his mission to woo the colleges, ensuring that they signed up early on to his plan for a new national health service.

They also largely spoke for hospital consultants rather than GPs. It was from his talks with the Royal Colleges that Bevan’s famous phrase “I stuffed their mouths with gold” hails: he got his plans over the line with those doctors by allowing them to continue private practice within NHS hospitals.

They then offered a solution to the continuing stand-off with the BMA in the final months before the service was due to start. Lord Moran, the president of the Royal College of Physicians, suggested an amendment to the National Health Service Act which would clarify that Bevan couldn’t force doctors to become full-time salaried employees of the state (a key fear of the profession). The BMA agreed.

The BMA always tends to march its members too far up a hill and require rescuing like this. In 2016, its strike action by juniors collapsed when leaked WhatsApp messages revealed the Junior Doctor’s Committee was plotting to “draw out” its battle with the Government and suggested it was fighting over pay, not patient safety, as it had told its members.

In the 70s, it lost huge credibility with its strikes over Barbara Castle’s plans to end the private practice Bevan had offered as a concession to get the service going. If the Royal Colleges move en masse in a pro-reform direction, maybe even talking doctors down from their current hill, then the rug would disappear from under the BMA once again. Any minister serious about the future of the NHS should learn not from the fight its founder had with its opponents, but from the charm offensive he conducted to ensure it exists at all.
Isabel Hardman is assistant editor of ‘The Spectator’ magazine. She writes a fortnightly column on health policy for i

title: The highest tax burden since 1948 is the Tories’ biggest identity crisis yet
lead: The identity crisis is giving Suella Braverman and other MPs an opportunity to make their case
author: Isabel Hardman

body.text: Rishi Sunak wants to use the Tory party conference, which starts this weekend in Manchester, to give his party and the country some “hard truths”. But here’s one hard truth that you probably won’t hear the Prime Minister dwelling on when he takes to the stage on Wednesday: the Tories have ended up being the party of high taxes.

Yes, that’s the pre-conference assessment of the Institute for Fiscal Studies, which on Thursday warned that by the end of this parliament, the tax burden will be at a post-war high, at about 37 per cent of national income. This isn’t a blip, either, according IFS Director Paul Johnson, who says “in my view this is almost certainly a permanent increase in taxes”. Yikes. Not something you’ll hear Sunak reciting in a list of Tory achievements.

But it’s a problem that Conservative MPs and ministers have been talking noisily about for months. They see the high tax burden as the most acute expression of a wider party identity crisis, and some are dismissive of the argument from Sunak and his chancellor Jeremy Hunt that it is “virtually impossible” to cut taxes at the moment when the government’s priority has to be fighting inflation.
Related Article
Rishi Sunak is trying to do what Nick Clegg did in 2010 – but he's forgetting one vital point

Liz Truss will be at the conference making the argument for lower taxes, and while activists might dismiss her as the woman who people still shout about on the doorstep, her points remain potent in the party and will be repeated in other fringe meetings by MPs who never thought she was suitable to be Prime Minister.
“We need at least an indication from Jeremy and Rishi that they don’t think high taxes are something Conservatives can be relaxed about,” says one former minister.
They said: “Fine, we’re not going to get any commitments at conference but what we still need and have been asking for for well over a year now is a sense of urgency.”

It’s not simple. Growth is sluggish, which makes it hard to find the cash. So does high public spending, and while Sunak regularly complains that people, including his own MPs, have come to think the Government has a role in everything, he also knows that there are huge spending areas that he simply cannot touch, such as the NHS.

Sunak and Hunt are similar Conservatives in many ways: they are both technocrats without a particular political mission. Hunt is very loyal to his boss and doesn’t have the same agenda that many ambitious chancellors (including Sunak when he held the role) have.

He also tends to defer to the PM more than other chancellors (including, once again, Sunak) have done in the past. To a certain extent, their political philosophy can be defined as “getting things done properly”, which in fairness is a pretty ambitious goal at the moment. But it also means that beyond the hard truths, we are unlikely to get a speech or an overall conference that gives us much of an idea of what kind of Conservatism this current party represents, other than a confused one.

It’s not just tax. Part of the Prime Minister’s vision for this autumn is of him as a slayer of monsters that other politicians have allowed to grow far beyond their original size. Changing the way Britain meets its net zero commitments was one example, while Sunak’s desire to prune HS2 in some way is another.

Neither are straightforward, either – they reflect the identity crisis in a party which for a few years had a green tree as its logo and which is still claiming to be levelling up the UK, including the city where it is holding its conference. Does it still care about giving the north of England the same infrastructure as the south-east and London, or is it retreating to a defensive crouch over the Home Counties come the next election? Do you vote blue to go green, or is green the colour of the left?

The identity crisis gives other leading figures such as Suella Braverman an opportunity to make their case. The One Nation group of Tories doesn’t have many red lines, but leaving the European Convention on Human Rights is one of them, and the Home Secretary’s threat on that this week horrified its members, including ministers who she has to work with. She is more interested in the soul-searching that might come after an election, but the Prime Minister’s lack of authority means Braverman can get her campaign started now, rather than waiting for a defeat and another leadership contest.

Boris Johnson, who bears a big responsibility for the huge tax burden, had his own approach to Tory identity. In the run-up to the 2019 general election, he booted out MPs who disagreed with him on Brexit, and ensured that the candidates who stood for the party all agreed with his “get Brexit done” pledge.

But Sunak isn’t that kind of politician, and none of the issues, not even net zero, are sufficiently visceral to enable that kind of purge. Not only that, but Johnson was removing people he saw as a barrier to Brexit. The barrier to lower taxes is, in the eyes of many Conservative MPs, the leader himself.

title: Tories turn on ‘dangerous’ Suella Braverman for fuelling far-right anger ahead of pro-Palestine march
lead: Minister tells i the Home Secretary is ‘fuelling’ far right as MP suggests support is draining away on Tory WhatsApp groups
author: Arj Singh

body.text: Suella Braverman has been accused by senior Conservatives of “whipping up” community tensions and increasing the prospect of violence at a pro-Palestine march and far-right counter demonstrations on Saturday.

The Home Secretary was branded “dangerous and totally irresponsible” by a serving Tory minister for “fuelling” the prospects of disorder after branding pro-Palestine protests “hate marches” and putting pressure on the police to ban Saturday’s demo.
“Her job is to calm things,” the minister told i, after Informfully revealed that police believe far-right groups and football hooligans pose the main risk of violence at counter-protests.

Tory ex-housing minister Gavin Barwell also criticised the Home Secretary, saying Ms Braverman was “retoxifying” the Tory brand with her use of language and angering Tory MPs by positioning herself for a future leadership challenge.

Rishi Sunak has joined Ms Braverman in criticising the decision to hold the pro-Palestine rally on Armistice Day on 11 November amid fears commemorations could be spoiled or the Cenotaph targeted ahead of Remembrance Sunday events the following day.

But the Prime Minister and Cabinet ministers have refused to repeat Ms Braverman’s characterisation of the pro-Palestine demonstrations that have taken place weekly in London since the start of the Gaza war as “hate marches”.

One Tory MP suggested support for Ms Braverman was ebbing away on the backbenches with only a “small number on the hard right of the party” defending her in WhatsApp groups while the rest were “at best disappointed, or at worst horrified by her divisive rhetoric on both the tents and the marches”.

The MP told i: “Although the overwhelming majority of us agree that the marches should not go ahead this weekend, her tone and language comes across as very inflammatory and is stoking up the tension that could lead to violence and rioting on Armistice weekend should they proceed as planned.
“Her comments only appeal to a certain core of voters and not the moderate right-thinking ones we need to be winning back prior to the next election.”
A third MP said Ms Braverman was “whipping people up carelessly and callously”.
“I’m not sure whether she is stupid or if she is trying to deliberately stoke tension,” the MP added.
“All I want is a home secretary who can calm community tensions, not stoke them.
“Every time she opens her mouth she makes things worse.”

Several senior ministers have also been forced to distance themselves from Ms Braverman’s suggestions that rough sleeping was sometimes a “lifestyle choice”, while Tory Party deputy chair Nickie Aiken on Wednesday insisted the demos “are not hate marches”.
Related Article
Braverman's homeless plan not signed off by Sunak and officials 'learned of it from her tweets'
“We have to be very, very careful about the language we use as politicians,” she told BBC Radio 5 Live.

International Development Minister Andrew Mitchell meanwhile told the Commons on Wednesday: “In terms of what the Home Secretary said, we are all responsible for what we say and she said it in the way that she did.”
Mr Barwell, Theresa May’s former chief of staff in No 10, told i: “It is her language that is the problem.

“If you take the most recent example, I suspect the vast majority of voters would agree with her that we don’t want people living on the streets and that drug taking, aggressive begging and so on are a problem.

“But they would not share her view that people are choosing to live on the streets – that even those who turn down an offer of a hostel place do so because they have complex problems, not because they like living as they are living.

“I also think there is increasing anger among Conservative MPs about her behaviour, which they perceive to be about positioning herself for a future leadership election rather than trying to support the PM.”

Meanwhile, a former intelligence official who now works for a Government department told i: “It is pretty depressing to see how this issue has been hijacked by extremists on both sides making it even harder to find some kind of middle ground.
“I don’t envy the Met Police Commissioner with a difficult operational dilemma to deal with and with Sunak and Suella breathing down his neck.”

Sir Keir Starmer has accused Mr Sunak of “cowardice” for “picking a fight” with the Metropolitan Police for not banning Saturday’s march after he hauled the Commissioner Sir Mark Rowley into Downing Street to hold him “accountable” for his decision.
The Labour leader said: “The person the PM needs to hold accountable is his Home Secretary. Picking a fight with the police instead of working with them is cowardice.
“The Tories put party before country. Labour will deliver the change Britain needs.”
Meanwhile, Tory former Cabinet minister Esther McVey claimed Ms Braverman was fearful of being sacked by Mr Sunak and so was attempting to shore up her right-wing base.
“I think she’s feeling very vulnerable,” she told GB News.

“I think that the immigration problem hasn’t been solved. So what she needs to do is, as she’d see it, is shore up a base, a base on the right hand side of the party, one that Rishi can’t naturally reach out to.
“What she’s saying is, you can’t get rid of me.
“There is a reshuffle coming forward and she’s saying, I’m going to be quite ‘out there’… I have to stay in.”
This story has been updated.

title: Covid inquiry: Five things we’ve learnt from Boris Johnson’s former most senior civil servant Mark Sedwill
lead: The Cabinet Secretary has been speaking about his time helping government deal with the early response to the pandemic
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: The Covid inquiry is continuing to examine the Government’s response to the Covid pandemic. The latest hearing is listening to the testimony of Lord Mark Sedwill, the former Cabinet Secretary and chief civil servant who admitted the Government was sluggish in its initial reaction to the crisis.
Here is what we have learnt so far:
Pox apology
Lord Sedwill apologised for a “heartless”-seeming suggestion that chicken pox-style parties could be held for coronavirus early in the pandemic.
Addressing families of coronavirus victims, Lord Sedwill told the Covid inquiry: “These were private exchanges and I certainly had not expected for this to become public.

“I understand how, in particular, the interpretation that has been put on it, it must have come across as someone in my role was both heartless and thoughtless about this, and I genuinely am neither. But I do understand the distress that must have caused and I apologise for that.”
Johnson’s stamina
In the wake of Boris Johnson contracting Covid, Lord Sedwill questioned the former prime minister’s “stamina” during his long recovery from the disease.
Lord Sedwill told the Covid inquiry: “It took him a long time to recover, he had a serious bout of this.
“So, I wasn’t concerned so much about his decision-making style – separate question – it was about stamina really.”
Edge of panic
The former civil servant said he felt he needed to show “confidence” so as to avoid creating panic among officials despite his own private misgivings about the situation..
He said: “I felt I had to provide leadership to a system that was on the edge of panic at that point.
Related Article
UK Covid death toll explained and timeline of lockdown restrictions

“I didn’t have the luxury of even in private saying ‘we’re doomed, the system’s broken, everyone is useless’ because even if I said that in private, it would have spread across the system and risked causing panic.

“So, what I saw my job as was to stay calm. No matter, notwithstanding my own anxieties but to stay calm, and to project confidence, not overconfidence, but confidence in the people who were working their way through this.”
‘Brutal and useless’
Lord Sedwill acknowledged that it was likely he said that Mr Johnson’s Government was “brutal and useless”.
In a diary entry from August 2020, Sir Patrick Vallance wrote that Lord Sedwill had complained “this administration is brutal and useless”.

The former Cabinet secretary said he could not remember making those remarks, but added: “I can’t actually recall what might have prompted it but… I don’t doubt Sir Patrick’s memory. It must have been a moment of acute frustration with something.”
No dictators
Lord Sedwill warned Dominic Cummings that the Government was not a “dictatorship” amid pandemic preparation in mid-March.
In an email shared with the inquiry, dated March 11, Mr Cummings asked for a meeting “chaired by me or Lee (Cain), so we are in position to answer Qs properly for PM at 9”.
He complained that the meeting that day had “involved a load of people from comms baffled about POLICY”.

Lord Sedwill responded: “We are not running a dictatorship here and the PM is not taking nationally significant decisions with a bunch of No10 SpAds and no ministers, no operational experts and no scientists. If necessary, I will take over the 8:15 slot and chair a daily meeting myself.”

title: Keir Starmer faces more pressure over Gaza as Labour MP Zarah Sultana tables amendment calling for ceasefire
lead: Imran Hussain resigned after being informed by Labour whips he could no longer formally support a ceasefire and maintain his job
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Sir Keir Starmer faces another potential test to his authority after a Labour MP tabled an amendment to the King’s Speech urging Parliament to back an “immediate ceasefire” in Gaza.
Zarah Sultana, MP for Coventry South, put forward the amendment in the wake of Imran Hussain’s resignation from the party frontbench over over the party’s position on the conflict.

The amendment will post another leadership test for Sir Keir who has battled to maintain party unity over his refusal to back a ceasefire and insistence that a “humanitarian pause” is the correct approach.
Mr Hussain, MP for Bradford East, was told by Labour whips he could no longer formally support a ceasefire and maintain his job as shadow minister for the New Deal for Working People.

He had been among several frontbenchers to have backed calls for a ceasefire but was the only one who signed a parliamentary motion, tabled by backbencher Richard Burgon, going against the party line.

The MP was told by party whips that if he decided to sign the new version of the amendment, tabled for this parliamentary session, he would not be able remain on the frontbench, Informfully understands.
As a result Mr Hussain made the decision to stand down on Tuesday.
The move signals Sir Keir’s crackdown on party discipline after facing accusations he had disregarded the rule of collective responsibility by not punishing junior shadow ministers for rebelling.
In a speech last week, the Labour leader insisted collective responsibility was “important” and something he took seriously.
Previously Labour insiders said the party leader would sack Shadow Cabinet ministers for speaking out against the party line but more leniency would be shown to junior frontbenchers.
But the resignation of Mr Hussain indicated Sir Keir has ramped up the expectation of party unity and was attempting to draw a line under recent revolt.
Now, Ms Sultana’s amendment could cause yet more headaches for Sir Keir.
If selected, it would be voted on at the conclusion of the King’s Speech debate next Wednesday.

It is not clear whether the amendment would be chosen by Commons Speaker, Sir Lindsay Hoyle, but if it was the Labour leader would have to make a decision about whether to whip his MPs to vote against it.
Doing so could spark a revolt in the highest ranks of the party as any frontbencher who rebelled would be forced to step down. Not doing so could potentially make Sir Keir look weak.

The amendment “utterly condemns Hamas’ appalling killing of Israeli civilians and taking of hostages” and “agrees with the United Nations Secretary-General that these crimes do not justify the collective punishment of the Palestinian people”.
Related Article
Tories turn on 'dangerous' Braverman for fuelling far-right anger ahead of Palestine march

It goes on to “call on the Government to urgently press all parties to agree to an immediate ceasefire, the immediate and unconditional release of hostages, an end to the total siege of Gaza to allow full access to medical supplies, food, fuel, electricity and water, and a guarantee that international humanitarian law is upheld.”

It has been signed by Labour backbench MPs including John McDonnell, Dr Rosena Allin-Khan and Richard Burgon, as well as Green MP Caroline Lucas, Plaid Cymru Westminster Group Leader Liz Saville Roberts MP and the SDLP’s Claire Hanna.
On Tuesday, shadow education secretary Bridget Phillipson warned her colleagues to “always carefully choose their words” when expressing views about the Israel-Hamas conflict.

Speaking on Times Radio, Ms Phillipson said: “I would urge colleagues to always carefully choose their words where it comes to fast-moving international events, and where it isn’t always clear or apparent very quickly what is happening on the ground.”

A Labour Party spokesman said: “Labour fully understands calls for a ceasefire. Everybody wants to see an end to the shocking images we are seeing in Gaza. We need to see all hostages released and aid getting to those most in need.
“But a ceasefire now will only freeze this conflict and would leave hostages in Gaza and Hamas with the infrastructure and capability to carry out the sort of attack we saw on October 7.
“International law must be followed at all times and innocent civilians must be protected. Labour is calling for humanitarian pauses in the fighting.
“This is the best and most realistic way to address the humanitarian emergency in Gaza and is a position shared by our major allies.”

title: Covid inquiry: Former cabinet chief wanted Matt Hancock sacked to ‘save lives and protect the NHS’
lead: Former top civil servant said work ‘should have continued’ on Covid work
author: Richard Vaughan

body.text: The UK’s former top civil servant suggested Boris Johnson should sack his then health secretary Matt Hancock in order to “save lives and protect the NHS” claiming he lied in meetings, the Covid inquiry has heard.

In another extraordinary day of the investigation into the pandemic, Lord Mark Sedwill shared WhatsApp messages with his would-be successor Simon Case stating he believed Mr Hancock should be fired over his performance dealing with the crisis.
In what he described as “gallows humour” in reference to the Covid slogan, “Stay home, protect the NHS, save lives”, Lord Sedwill told Mr Case the former health secretary should have been sacked.
“I had raised my concerns with the prime minister. That was not intended for him to remove Mr Hancock but to take a grip on the issue.
He said he did not use the word “sack” with the prime minister.
“But I did use it in a WhatsApp with Simon Case”, he said.
He added that while he did not provide any formal advice to sack Mr Hancock, he told the hearing Mr Johnson “would have been under no illusions as to my view about what was best”.
The comments came after Lord Sedwill confirmed that he believed Mr Hancock had lied in meetings and officials were forced to clarify his claims.

Hugo Keith KC, counsel for the inquiry, asked the peer: “The process by which Mr Hancock’s truthfulness, or candour, or lack of candour or general approach, was not confined to one or two individuals?”
Lord Sedwill replied: “Yes.”
The inquiry also heard how Mr Case complained to Lord Sedwill that working with Mr Johnson and his team was akin to “taming wild animals”.

In messages with his predecessor Lord Mark Sedwill, Mr Case, then-permanent secretary in No 10, wrote on June 5 2020: “It is like taming wild animals. Nothing in my past experience has prepared me for this madness.
“The PM and the people he chooses to surround himself with are basically feral.”
Lord Sedwill replied: “I have the bite marks.”
The crossbench peer also criticised Mr Johnson’s decision to go on holiday for 10 days just weeks before the Government was forced to lockdown the country.
He said he believed preparatory work for the pandemic “should have continued” when Mr Johnson was on leave at a time that coincided with half term.

During the period in mid-February 2020, the former prime minister received no notes or emails related to coronavirus, despite countries, such as Italy locking down vast swathes of their countries in a bid to contain the disease.
Asked about the drop-off in work on pandemic preparation, he said: “I would have expected it to continue, yes.”
He also conceded that by the end of February levels of alarm inside the Government, given official warnings about the imminent crisis, “should have been” higher.

“It’s hard looking back to recall quite how extraordinary were the measures we later took. They were unconscionable at the time. And, therefore, I think your point about this instinctive human reaction is true.
“I think it was also the case at the end of February the number of cases in the UK was – on the data available – still very small.
Related Article
5 things learned from Johnson's chief of staff and ex-head of Covid taskforce at the inquiry
“One can understand how non-experts not familiar with exponential movement might have misunderstood the pace at which the disease was moving.”
He acknowledged that Mr Johnson might have shared that optimism bias.
“He is an optimistic person,” he told the hearing.

Lord Sedwill told the inquiry that he was not aware that UK transmission was taking place in early March, despite the Covid group SPI-M confirming that it was and before the Government had even published its Covid plan.
The crossbench peer also admitted that the scientific advice early on in the pandemic meant ministers were not reacting with the urgency that it required.

Questioned about a remark by Mr Johnson at a Cabinet meeting on February 6 when he said  “confidence is contagious”, Lord Sedwill replied: “If you look earlier… it is still the case that the scientific advice is essentially suggesting that the worst-case scenario is unlikely, is indeed very unlikely. So that, undoubtedly, would have informed the way ministers were thinking about this.
“The prime minister in that summary is trying to balance the tensions.”
In a diary entry from August 2020, Sir Patrick Vallance wrote that Lord Sedwill had complained “this administration is brutal and useless”.

The former Cabinet secretary said he could not remember making those remarks, but added: I can’t actually recall what might have prompted it but… I don’t doubt Sir Patrick’s memory. It must have been a moment of acute frustration with something.”
Lord Sedwill also admitted that the very top of government was not aware that Covid transmission was taking place in the UK despite it being reported by scientific groups set up by the Government.

title: Why is there no PMQs today? When it will return to House of Commons
lead: Following the formal State Opening of Parliament on Tuesday there will be no Prime Minister’s Questions in the House of Commons today
author: Sally Guyoncourt

body.text: After the pomp and ceremony of the State Opening of Parliament it is not quite business as usual in the House of Commons this week.
King Charles formally opened a new session in Parliament yesterday, with the King’s Speech setting out the programme of legislation the Government intends to pursue for the year ahead.
But the Wednesday routine of Prime Minister’s Questions (PMQs) will not return this week.
We take a look at why and when it will be back.
Why is there no PMQs today?
Rishi Sunak and Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer normally spar in the Commons over the issues of the past week each Wednesday at midday.
The televised sessions also give the public an opportunity to judge the two leaders as they vie for popularity ahead of the next general election.
However, Prime Minister’s Questions has been delayed this week because there is now a debate on the King’s Speech.
Known as the debate on the address, it began on Tuesday and takes precedence for six sitting days in the House of Commons.
And so the next PMQs will be held on Wednesday 15 November at midday.
In the meantime, the Prime Minister left London today to visit a school in Lincolnshire.
This is the second consecutive week in which there has been no PMQs.
What happened last week?
There was no PMQs last week as Parliament was prorogued, putting an end to that session and clearing the way for a new one.
Each session normally lasts about a year, with a number of recesses. The prorogation is followed by a short break before a new session begins.
How to watch the next PMQs
PMQs in the Commons Chamber is a ticketed event, with tickets available to UK residents free of charge via their Member of Parliament or a member of the House of Lords.
The session is also televised so the public has the opportunity to watch proceedings.

title: Why the pro-Gaza protest hasn’t been banned and how it could still be stopped by authorities
lead: Met Police chief Sir Mark Rowley said he had ‘no absolute power’ to ban the protest because intelligence on the potential for serious disorder did not meet the threshold
author: Chloe Chaplain

body.text: Despite political pressure on police to ban the pro-Palestinian demonstration planned for Armistice Day, the march is set to go ahead as planned.
Met Police chief Sir Mark Rowley said on Tuesday evening he had “no absolute power” to ban the protest because intelligence on the potential for serious disorder did not meet the threshold.
“The laws created by parliament are clear. There is no absolute power to ban protest, therefore there will be a protest this weekend,” Sir Mark said.
He also stated that whilst there are laws to ban marches in certain situations, there is no way to ban a static demonstration.
“The law provides no mechanism to ban a static gathering of people,” he said.

“It contains legislation which allows us to impose conditions to reduce disruption and the risk of violence, and in the most extreme cases when no other tactics can work, for marches or moving protests to be banned.”
What powers do police have?
In certain situations, the police could request the power to ban the event under Section 13 of the Public Order Act 1986.
This would involve a police force – which are operationally independent from the government – carrying out a review of the planned event and any intelligence as to the potential for disruption.
Related Article
Banning pro-Palestinian protest on Armistice Day may lead to bigger turnout, ex officer warns
Before that point is reached, there are several other mitigating powers police could draw on.
Section 14 of the Act permits police to restrict the number of people taking part in a protest, the location of it or its maximum duration.
Similarly, there are additional powers under Section 12 which allow police to enforce other restrictions on the event.

This would apply if a force believes a protest may result in “serious public disorder, serious damage to property or serious disruption” or if the purpose is to intimidate others into doing, or not doing, something.

Such conditions would be designed to mitigate any disruption and could see officers imposing rules as to the route of the procession or prohibiting it from entering any public place specified in the directions.
The law empowers police to act and conditions can be imposed in advance or by a senior police officer at the scene.
How would a ban be imposed?
In the event that the force concluded there was the threat of serious public disorder that could not be controlled by these other measures, the police could then request a Section 13.
If this decision is taken by the senior constable, it must be approved by the local council (other than in London) as well as the home secretary.
Related Article
Armistice Day protest won't be banned, says Met chief - as police prepare for months of unrest
A ban such as this would not just apply to the protest of concern but all marches in the area.

As Sir Mark said in his statement, use of such a power to block moving protests is “incredibly rare” and must be reserved for cases where there is intelligence to suggest a “real threat” of serious disorder.
The concern, stressed by Rishi Sunak and other senior politicians, was that the event would be taking place on the same day as Remembrance events at the Cenotaph, in central London.

But Sir Mark said organisers of Saturday’s march had shown “complete willingness to stay away from the Cenotaph and Whitehall and have no intention of disrupting the nation’s Remembrance events”. He said if this should change he would use all powers available.
The ban would only apply to moving protests and would not prevent a static demonstration, known as an assembly, of people. These can be hit with restrictions but not banned from taking place.
Could Suella Braverman overrule the decision?
In very extreme circumstances, Home Secretary Suella Braverman has power under Section 40A of The Police Act 1996 to “give direction” to override a decision taken by a force.

If the secretary of state “believe[s] the police force is failing to discharge any of its functions in an effective manner, whether generally or in particular respects, he may direct the [local policing body] to take specified measures for the purpose of remedying the failure”, the Act states.
This power is designed to be used as a last resort for the home secretary to intervene in a police force that is considered to be failing.

It also involved a stipulation that the secretary of state must put to the chief officer evidence that the force is failing, and give them the chance to make representations and suggest their own proposals for the taking of remedial measures.
Using this power would be hugely controversial – is it not designed to be imposed purely because ministers disagree with a decision taken by an operationally independent police force.

title: The Tories have laid a net zero trap for Labour. It won’t work
lead: ‘If they are trying to set a trap for Labour, I don’t think it’s going to cut through’
author: Arj Singh

body.text: Rishi Sunak’s attempts to use the King’s Speech to draw election battle lines are likely to backfire because he has picked the wrong policies, pollsters have said.

Plans for more North Sea oil and gas drilling and tough crime and justice measures were at the centre of the Prime Minister’s legislative programme. Both were attempts to frame next year’s election campaign on issues where the Conservatives believe they can trap Labour into positions at odds with voters.

But pollsters believe the execution has been flawed, with the moves on oil and gas likely to be seen as “weird” by voters. And Tory insiders fear the electorate is unlikely to “believe” plans for tougher sentences when prisoners are being released early from full jails.
Mr Sunak has already signalled a major row-back on net-zero policies which he believes will appeal to voters concerned about the cost.

The announcement of more North Sea drilling is being seen an attempt to build on that and make things difficult for Labour, which has pledged to ban new gas and oil licences as part of its drive for net zero.

But Luke Tryl, director of More In Common, told Informfully that Mr Sunak was right to focus on the debate on whether “we need to do net zero sensibly”, and stressed that voters in focus groups chime with the Government’s insistence that “they don’t want to be dependent on madmen like Putin (for energy) again”.
But the former Tory special adviser turned pollster warned that the PM’s strategy would backfire.
“What the public hear is: we’re drilling in the North Sea again, which for lots of people comes across as a bit weird,” he said.
“Politicians try to be too clever by half and if they are trying to set a trap for Labour, I don’t think it’s going to cut through.”

YouGov’s Patrick English said the King’s Speech appeared to be the latest attempt to “fight the next election on the issues they want to talk about and get Labour to fall down on the wrong side of public opinion”.
He told Informfully the Tories believe they are close to the “median voter position” on net zero – that “we can’t be making ordinary people pay for it so we need to be ‘sensible and pragmatic’”.
But he added: “I don’t think the trap [on oil and gas] is there…
“I don’t think is the right signal to the median voter that climate change is being taken seriously.”

But both pollsters agreed that Mr Sunak was right to focus on tougher sentences, with Mr Tryl saying he “understands” why the PM has “doubled down on crime” as it is a “bread and butter issue the Conservatives should be leading on”.

“What we saw today, the tough on crime stuff, the North Sea stuff, is about that ‘don’t know’ group who we know are more right-wing than the average voter – a lot of them are disgruntled Conservatives,” he added.

“If they don’t get any Labour votes back they are going to lose, but the don’t knows could be the difference between a defeat and a 1997-style defeat is disgruntled Conservatives not turning up to vote.
“A lot of what we are seeing is re-engaging that group, getting back to 30-32 per cent, which means you are in the running if the economy then improves.”

But a Tory insider warned that tougher sentences for serious criminals also risks backfiring when Justice Secretary Alex Chalk is simultaneously having to announce plans to keep less serious offenders away from jails which are more or less full.
“No one will believe sentencing after Chalk opened the prison gates, it’s mad,” the insider said.

The Institute for Government’s Joe Owen suggested some of the 20 Bills announced on Tuesday may never make it on to the statute book and may simply be designed to throw up awkward Commons votes in the run-up to an election.
“There are a handful of key bills where they would prefer to have big votes in the Commons later in the year, to create some dividing lines prior to an election.

“Some of these bills might be more about pushing the opposition into whipping votes on politically tricky topics, or the theatre in Parliament in the next 12 months, rather than precisely what they do to the statute book.”
Labour, meanwhile, appeared relaxed about the Mr Sunak’s plans.

Tony Blair’s former political strategist John McTernan suggested they were more likely to “lead to splits in the Tory Party” than trouble Labour in an election, pointing to the proposal to ban smoking for everyone aged 14 and under today.
“You’ve got a wedge issue which wedges your own party,” he said.
“This will split them on whether they are libertarians or nannies, that will bring about brutal internal divisions, in a way that Gaza has brought about quite fundamental splits in Labour.”
On oil and gas Mr McTernan argues there is a “contradiction” between “tactics and strategy”.
“The Tories have a strategy of saying we are world beating in everything, except in this one place where we (actually) are world beating – net zero – they don’t want to do it,” he said.
“The biggest trap is for Labour to spend the next three months falling down laughing.”
Potential King’s Speech traps for Labour
Offshore Petroleum Licensing Bill: Designed as a way for Mr Sunak to expand on his argument that Labour is putting ideology before pragmatism on net zero. Potential trap rating: 2/5

Sentencing Bill: Much tougher sentences for violent and sadistic offenders, largely backed by Labour, could give the Tories a way into scrutinising Sir Keir Starmer’s record as director of public prosecutions. Potential trap rating: 2/5
Economic Activities of Public Bodies Bill: Laws to stop councils boycotting Israel risk deepening damaging Labour splits over the conflict in Gaza. Potential trap rating: 3/5

Minimum Service Levels: Technically not part of the King’s Speech legislative programme but mentioned in the speech, the restrictions on public-sector strikes could be tricky if it forces Labour to essentially tell voters they could face more disruption under Sir Keir. Potential trap rating: 4/5

title: Labour frontbencher Imran Hussain resigns over party’s stance on ceasefire in Gaza
lead: The shadow minister said his view on the “humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza” differs “substantially” from Sir Keir Starmer’s
author: Jacqui Housden

body.text: A Labour frontbencher has resigned to “strongly advocate for a ceasefire” between Israel and Hamas, adding to pressure on Sir Keir Starmer over his position on the conflict.

Imran Hussain, MP for Bradford East, said he was stepping back from his role as shadow minister for the New Deal for Working People as it had become clear his view “differs substantially” from the party leader’s.
Labour will not change its stance on the ceasefire, despite the resignation, party spokesperson said.

In a letter to Sir Keir, published on X, Mr Hussain wrote: “It is with a heavy heart that I am writing to tender my resignation as Shadow Minister for the New Deal for Working People after eight years on the Labour Party frontbench.”
“A ceasefire is essential to ending the bloodshed, to ensuring that enough aid can pass into Gaza and reach those most in need,” he wrote.

In his post on X he added: “I want to be able to strongly advocate for a ceasefire, as called for by the UN General Secretary. In order to be fully free to do so, I have tonight stepped down from Labour’s Frontbench.”

I want to be able to strongly advocate for a ceasefire, as called for by the UN General Secretary. In order to be fully free to do so, I have tonight stepped down from Labour's Frontbench. My letter below: pic.twitter.com/u47KMVNhxt

He said he had been “proud” to work alongside Sir Keir and his deputy Angela Rayner in developing a plan for employment rights, but could not “in all good conscience” push for a cessation of hostilities while remaining part of the frontbench.
Mr Hussain said: “It has become clear that my view on the ongoing humanitarian catastrophe in Gaza differs substantially from the position you have adopted.”
The MP said he unequivocally condemned Hamas’ 7 October terror attack but said this could not “become a right to violate international law on protecting civilians or to commit war crimes”.
“As I write, more than 1,400 Israeli and over 10,000 Palestinian civilians have been killed in the last month,” he wrote.
“This shocking number of fatalities is set to grow as indiscriminate attacks and the siege of Gaza continues.”
Mr Hussain had served on Labour’s frontbench for almost eight years, serving under Jeremy Corbyn’s leadership as shadow international development minister in 2016.
His resignation comes as Sir Keir faces growing pressure from within his party over the conflict, with dozens of councillors quitting Labour in protest.
Many of his Shadow Cabinet have also broken ranks to back calls for a ceasefire in the region.
Sir Keir has announced a compromise position of backing a ceasefire once Israelis taken hostage taken by Hamas are freed.
He attracted criticism shortly after Hamas first attacked Israel last month when he appeared to suggest Israel had a right to limit essential supplies, including water and electricity, to Gaza.
Last month, 150 councillors jointly signed a letter to Sir Keir and deputy leader Angela Rayner requesting that Labour back a ceasefire.

A Labour party spokesperson said: “Labour fully understands calls for a ceasefire. Everybody wants to see an end to the shocking images we are seeing in Gaza. We need to see all hostages released and aid getting to those most in need.
“But a ceasefire now will only freeze this conflict and would leave hostages in Gaza and Hamas with the infrastructure and capability to carry out the sort of attack we saw on October the 7th.

“International law must be followed at all times and innocent civilians must be protected. Labour is calling for humanitarian pauses in the fighting. This is the best and most realistic way to address the humanitarian emergency in Gaza and is a position shared by our major allies.”

title: Armistice Day protest won’t be banned, says Met chief – as police prepare for months of marches over Gaza
lead: Despite political pressure, Metropolitan Police Service commissioner Sir Mark Rowley said the power to ban a protest should only be a ‘last resort’ and the threshold has not been met
author: Hugo Gye

body.text: A march through London planned for this Saturday is set to go ahead after the Metropolitan Police Service decided against imposing a ban to prevent a clash with Armistice Day.

Metropolitan Police Commissioner Sir Mark Rowley said on Tuesday that the ability to ban a protest was a measure that should only be a “last resort” – and the threshold for its use has not been reached.
“The laws created by Parliament are clear. There is no absolute power to ban protest, therefore there will be a protest this weekend,” he said.
“At this time, the intelligence surrounding the potential for serious disorder this weekend does not meet the threshold to apply for a ban.”

Ministers had been pushing Scotland Yard bosses to ban the planned demo in London over claims it would disrupt the next day’s Remembrance Sunday Day commemorations and set up a confrontation with far-right counter-protesters.

A Downing Street spokesman said: “The Prime Minister himself does not think it’s right for these sorts of protests to be scheduled on Armistice Day. He believes that is provocative and disrespectful.”

Veterans’ minister Johnny Mercer meanwhile raised concerns for “elderly veterans for whom travelling to London once a year is an important part of their Remembrance and have expressed genuine fears to me around their ability to travel to London, particularly through our rail stations, unmolested”.
Police chiefs and ministers are planning for anti-Israel protests to last for weeks or months as they step up planning for extended public disorder.

Policing leaders from across England have this week met with Suella Braverman to discuss how they handle the prospect of repeated demonstrations against Israel’s military activity in Gaza over a prolonged period of time.

One meeting took place on Monday where representatives of the Metropolitan Police and National Police Chiefs’ Council met the Home Secretary to lay out their proposals for “medium to long term planning”, a Whitehall source told i.
It is understood police forces from across the UK are set to offer increased support to the Met after 170 officers from 19 forces were deployed in the capital last weekend.

Thousands of demonstrators who have previously protested in cities such as Manchester and Birmingham will arrive in the capital this weekend if the protest goes ahead, with regional branches of the Palestine Solidarity Campaign (PSC) organising coach travel for supporters on Saturday. Meanwhile, far-right groups urged activists to head to the capital and “protect” the Cenotaph.
In a statement, Sir Mark said he was confident the Cenotaph was not under threat from the pro-Palestinian protest, planned to march from Hyde Park to the US Embassy in Vauxhall, south London.

He said: “The organisers have shown complete willingness to stay away from the Cenotaph and Whitehall and have no intention of disrupting the nation’s remembrance events. Should this change, we’ve been clear we will use powers and conditions available to us to protect locations and events of national importance at all costs.
“Officers will continue to take swift and robust action against any breakaway groups or individuals intent on using legitimate, lawful protest for their own agenda through Saturday and Sunday.

“If over the next few days the intelligence evolves, and we reach a threshold where there is a real threat of serious disorder we will approach the Home Secretary. Right now, we remain focused on the facts in front of us and developing our plan to ensure the highest levels of protection for events throughout the weekend.”
Of Ms Braverman’s past comments referring to the protests as “hate marches”, Sir Mark told the BBC: “I wouldn’t use one phrase to characterise 100,000 people.”

He said there are a “diverse range of people” attending pro-Palestinian marches, “many of whom are perfectly behaved and discharging their public right to protest” as well as “small groups of people who have been difficult and violent”.

The decision not to ban the protest was backed by Lord Soames, the former Armed Forces minister and grandson of Winston Churchill, who told LBC: “I think that a lot of people died during the war to assert freedom. And because you may not agree or disagree with their views and because it is very contentious and very difficult, it’s going to put tremendous strain on the police, I think it must be allowed to go ahead.
